bug.author: jgc128
bug.summary: Language.save_to_directory fails if the path is a string
bug.description:
Hi, The documentation says that the path argument in the Language.save_to_directory method can be a string. However, this methods fails in such case: <denchmark-code>File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/spacy/language.py", line 353, in save_to_directory self.setup_directory(path, **configs) File "lib/python3.6/site-packages/spacy/language.py", line 192, in setup_directory directory = path / name TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'str' and 'str' </denchmark-code>
It works fine if the argument is a pathlib's Path. <denchmark-h:h2>Your Environment</denchmark-h>
spaCy version: 1.8.0 Platform: Linux-4.4.0-66-generic-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-16.04-xenial Python version: 3.6.1 Installed models: en, en_core_web_md

comments.comment: Hmm, this is interesting! Could you share how you're calling save_to_directory(), i.e. the value you're passing in? spaCy currently uses an <denchmark-link:https://github.com/explosion/spaCy/blob/master/spacy/util.py#L43>ensure_path() helper function</denchmark-link> that should make sure string types are turned into pathlib paths. But somehow, this seems to fail here and returns a string...
Oh, I see - I was using the version from pip, and it does not call ensure_path in save_to_directory, whereas the version from github uses it. I'll close the issue then. Thanks!
Oh, I didn't realise this was a fix we hadn't released as part of v1.8.0 yet. The next point release will hopefully be up on pip later tonight! Sorry about the confusion.
